Many researchers have used nanoparticles as adsorbents to remove water pollutants including arsenic after modifying the properties of nanoparticles by improving reactivity, biocompatibility, stability, charge density, multi-functionalities, and dispersibility. For arsenic removal, nano adsorbents emerged as the potential alternatives to existing conventional technologies. The present study critically reviewed the past and current available information on the potential of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal from contaminated water and the challenges involved in that. The study discussed the separation and regeneration techniques of nano adsorbents and the performance thereof. The study evaluated the adsorption efficiency of the various nanoparticles based on size of nanoparticles, types of nano adsorbents, method of synthesis, separation and regeneration of the nano adsorbents. The study found that more studies are required on suitable holding materials for the nano adsorbents to improve the permeability and to make the technology applicable at the field condition. The study will help the readers to choose suitable nanomaterials and to take up further research required for arsenic removal using nano adsorbents.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water contamination due to increased population and industrial activities is one of the most challenging issues to the researchers, because it is continuously increasing threats to both human health and the environment. The main threats to human health from heavy metals contamination of water are associated with the exposure to different heavy metals and metalloids such as lead, cadmium, chromium, mercury and arsenic. The presence of these heavy metals and their effects on human health are studied and regularly reviewed by international bodies such as theWHO (J€arup, 2003). Out of these heavy metals, arsenic is found to pose maximum adverse effects on human health through arsenic contaminated drinking water. Mining wastes, petroleum refining, sewage sludge, agricultural chemicals, ceramic manufacturing industries, and coal fly ash are some of the anthropogenic activities that increase arsenic concentrations in surface water as well as groundwater (Viraraghavan et al., 1999). Natural sources such as weathering, erosion of rocks/soils and volcanic emissions also contribute arsenic in aqueous system. Naturally, arsenic occurs more than 200 different mineral forms. Of these, approximately 60% are arsenates, 20% are sulphides and sulphosalts, and the remaining 20% are arsenide, arsenite, oxides, silicates and elemental arsenic (Onishi, 1969). The main arsenic containing mineral arsenopyrite is formed by hydrothermal activity associated with the intrusion of granitic magma and orogenesis (Duarte et al., 2009). The occurrence of arsenic in drinking water can occur as a result of its natural geological presence in local bedrock (Garelick et al., 2008). In drinking water, it predominantly occurs as inorganic (arsenite, arsenate) and organic forms (methyl and dimethyl arsenic compounds) mainly in surface water (Smedley and Kinniburg, 2002). High-arsenic bearing waters are not expected where there is a high concentration of free sulphide, because in reducing condition it forms precipitate with arsenic (Moore et al., 1988). A recent publication reported that arsenic is a unique carcinogen. It is the only known human carcinogen for which there is adequate evidence of carcinogenic risk by both inhalation and ingestion (Centeno et al., 2006). In six administrative blocks of the district Murshidabad of West Bengal, India, about 1.25 million people are exposed to groundwater arsenic concentrations above 0.05 mg/L (Samadder, 2011). Considering its toxicity, WHO decided maximum permissible limit for arsenic as 0.01 mg/L in drinking water. Increasing risk of arsenic carcinogenicity for developing countries drawn the attention of the researchers to do more research on arsenic contamination and treatment for its removal. To treat the contaminated groundwater or surface water economically, methods such as oxidation (Pierce and Moore, 1982; Sorlini and Gialdini, 2010), co-precipitation (Choong et al., 2007; Kumar et al., 2004), adsorption (Zaspalis et al., 2007; Bhatnagar et al., 2010), ion-exchange (Anirudhan and Unnithan, 2007), and membrane technologies (Brandhuber and Amy, 2001) were used.
But the adsorption evolved as the most promising method among the available methods as this method does not add
undesirable by-products and the used adsorbents can be regenerated for reuse upto reasonably good number of cycles. However, adsorption has certain limitations also, such as it could not achieve a good status at commercial levels due to the lack of suitable adsorbents of high adsorption capacity and unavailability of commercial scale columns (Grassi et al., 2012). Moreover, same adsorbent is not effective for different types of water pollutants. For adsorption, various materials were used as adsorbents such as surfactants, synthetic activated carbon, industrial byproducts and wastes, ferrous material, iron based soil amendment, and mineral products (Hashim et al., 2011). To fulfil the objective of the development of an effective adsorbent that is active and rapid for arsenic removal, nano size adsorbents were developed by researchers. Macromolecules have intra-particle diffusion that decreases the adsorption rate and available capacity of the adsorbent, while nanoparticles have small diffusion resistance that increased the significance of the application of nanoparticles as adsorbent (Attia et al., 2012). Nanoparticles also have some distinctive properties such as small size, catalytic potential, large surface area, high reactivity, easy separation, and large number of active sites that facilitate better arsenic removal efficiency compared to other available adsorbents. Ngomsik et al. (2005) compared efficiency of nano and micro sized particles and concluded nano adsorbents as comparatively better than micro adsorbents, though micro particles have been studied extensively for metal extraction and have the advantage of easy separation. In the process of developing nano adsorbents, various transition metal based compounds have been explored as arsenic removing adsorbents such as Cu, Fe, and Ti. Other materials like alumina and polymers like vinylpyridine have also been modified for the preparation of nano adsorbents. Though nano adsorbents give better results compared to other adsorbents for arsenic removal, but there are two main challenges in using nanomaterials for water purification; one is the non-availability of nanomaterials at economically affordable prices and the other is the toxicity and the environmental fate of nanomaterials (Mostafa and Hoinkis, 2012). The cost is mainly dependent on availability, types, preparation and applicability in actual field conditions. Toxicity of nanomaterials increases with atomic number with the exceptions of Fe2O3 (lower toxicity than expected) and CoO (higher toxicity than expected) (Huang et al., 2010). There are many review papers available on arsenic removal using nano adsorbents, but this paper critically reviewed the comparative study of applicability and the challenges of selecting nanomaterials as adsorbents for removal of arsenic from drinking water.

sections.heading: 2. Applicability of various nano adsorbents
sections.text:
Development of nano adsorbent is regarded as the major step towards achieving the nanoscaling effects and properties that have been utilised by nature for millions of years. Nanoparticles are small atomic clusterswith<100 nmsize (Husein andNassar, 2008) andare efficient to remove arsenic 5e10 times more effectively than their micron size counterparts (Ponder et al., 2001; Sharma et al., 2009).

Several nanocomposites and nanoparticles have been used for removal of arsenic from drinking water. Nano adsorbents can transform toxic substances into non-toxic and can adsorb toxic substances by ion exchange, ion precipitation and adsorption. Nanocomposites are prepared using materials such as, ceramic or polymer matrices strengthened by nanoparticles (Nassar et al., 2005). In a study conducted by Hristovski et al. (2007), it was reported that some metal oxide nanoparticles may end up in effluent simply bywashing thepackedbeds, butothers such asNikel (Ni)may be dissolved in water prior to its treatment. Therefore, selection of nano adsorbents for removal of arsenic or other heavymetals should be done carefully to achieve maximum removal efficiency and easy separation. Variousmetal oxides of transitionmetals have been used for preparing nano adsorbent. Macroscopic studies showed that amorphous metal oxides have large adsorption capacities (per unit mass basis) due to their extremely high surface areas (Trivedi and Axe, 1999; Dixit and Hering, 2003). Different methods such as precipitation, solegel, hydrothermal, dry vapour deposition, surfactant mediation, micro emulsion, electro-deposition and sonochemical methodshavebeen reported in literature to synthesizenanoparticles (Husein and Nassar, 2008; Mohapatra and Anand, 2010).

sections.heading: 2.1. Different nano adsorbents for arsenic removal
2.1.1. Iron oxides/hydroxides nanoparticles
sections.text: Iron compounds such as hematite, goethite, iron oxide-coated materials and granular ferric hydroxide (GFH) are the preferred group of substances for arsenic adsorption because they lead to low leaching of adsorbed arsenic from exhausted adsorbent (Ghanizadeh et al., 2010). Nassar (2012) reported different types of iron oxides viz. hematite (a-Fe2O3), maghemite (g-Fe2O3), magnetite (Fe3O4), and wustite (FeO); oxides/hydroxides of iron viz. goethite (a-FeOOH), akagneite (b-FeOOH), lepidocrocite (d-FeOOH), feroxyhyte (d0 FeOOH); and hydroxides of iron viz. ferrihydrite (Fe5HO8$4H2O) and bernalite (Fe (OH)3). These iron nanoparticles have magnetic properties which facilitate easy separation from water using high gradient magnetic separation (HGMS) technique after adsorption. In addition to iron oxide nanoparticles, nanoparticles of its zero-valent form have also been reported for removal of metallic pollutants such as cadmium (Cd), zinc (Zn), selenium (Se), arsenic (As), chromium (Cr), silver (Ag) and lead (Pb) from drinking water and industrial effluents to prove its potential for environmental applications. Preparation of nano iron oxide particles is a challenging area of research as it requires careful selection of pH, concentration of the reactants, temperature, method of mixing, and rate of oxidation (Domingo et al., 1994). MamindyPajany et al. (2011) studied arsenate adsorption on goethite, hematite, magnetite and found arsenic adsorption is related to the iron content of adsorbents, and adsorption rate increases in the order of goethite < hematite <magnetite < ZVI. To enhance surface chemistry, particle stability and subsurfacemobility potential of the nanoscale zero-valent iron (NZVI) and polyvinyl alcohol-co-vinyl acetate-co-itaconic acid (PV3A), a nontoxic and biodegradable surfactant has been used by Sun et al. (2007). Sylvester et al. (2007) used ArsenXnp, a hybrid sorbent, consisting of nanoparticles of hydrous iron oxide distributed throughout a porous polymeric bead. Arsenate interactions with iron oxides are dominated by the formation of strong inneresphere complexes and to a lesser extent by weaker ion exchange reactions. Feng et al. (2012) coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles with ascorbic acid in aqueous suspensions that improved the dispersibility of nanoparticles as well as effectively inhibited the leaching of Fe into the solution.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Alumina nanoparticles
sections.text:
Alumina nanoparticles in chitosan-graft-polyacrylamide (CTS-
g-PA) was used as adsorbent for arsenic removal by Saha and Sarkar (2012). There were several reasons for grafting new functional groups: (a) to increase the density of the sorption sites, (b) to change the pH range for metal sorption, and (c) to change the sorption sites and/or the uptake mechanism in order to increase sorption selectivity for the targetmetal (Guibal, 2004). Darban et al. (2013) used inexpensive kaoline as raw material to produce nanoporous g-alumina by precipitation method with high surface area (201.53 m2/g) and small particle size (22e36 nm). This nanoalumina powder has good adsorption capacity and recovery efficiency. Jang et al. (2003) investigated the types of surface complexation and the rate of adsorption of nanostructured silicate media impregnated with metal oxides. For the removal of arsenate from groundwater they used mesoporous silica (SBA-15) as supporting media impregnated with metal oxides such as iron, aluminium and zinc. But aluminum-impregnated SBA-15 was found attributed to the fast adsorption capacity. The hexagonal open-pore structures of the MCM-41 (two-dimensional hexagonal mesopore structure) and more number of monodentate hydroxyl densities enhanced the accessibility and transport of arsenate species on adsorbent surface (Jang et al., 2003).

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Copper oxide nanoparticles
sections.text: Cupric oxide (CuO) was found as an effective arsenic removal nano adsorbent, because it did not require pH adjustments or oxidation of As (III) into As (V) and it performed well in the presence of competing anions (Reddy, 2007; Reddy and Attili, 2005). These nanoparticles are easy to regenerate and can be reused to remove arsenic from water. In a study, cupric oxide nanoparticles was used in polypropylene centrifuge tubes for batch study while sand was used as supporting material of nanoparticles for column study (Reddy et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Titanium dioxide nanoparticles
sections.text: Various properties of TiO2 such as chemical stability, low cost, nontoxicity and the resistance to corrosion (Hung et al., 2006), strong oxidizing power of the holes, redox selectivity, easy preparation, high affinity to arsenic and its inherent photo-oxidizing capability of As (III) into As (V) remove the need of pre-oxidation (Bang et al., 2005; Pena et al., 2006). Various authors used titanium as nanoporous titania and titatinum dioxide (Lee and Choi, 2002; Dutta et al., 2004; Pena et al., 2006) for arsenic removal. Han et al. (2010) studied surface complexation model (SCM) to explain the surface properties of nanoporous titania adsorbents (NTAs). After SCM study, they identified the type of surface species that contribute the apparent arsenic removal at specified pH. For adsorption of As (III) onto Ti(25)eSBA-15 monodentate surface complexes were found more efficient over wide range of pH, while bidentate surface complexes were found efficient for As (V) adsorption at pH 8 (Han et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Zinc oxide nanoparticles
sections.text: ZnO is a nontoxic and very stable material. Zinc oxide effectively works in the pH range of 5.8e6.8 that made it user friendly (Singh et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 2.1.6. Mixed metal oxide (MMO's) nanoparticles
sections.text:
Use of metal composite containing two or more metals inherits the advantages of parent oxides and shows synergistic effect of higher adsorption capacity rather than individual metal oxide. Various metal oxide composites such as FeeCe (Zhang et al., 2005), FeeMn (Kong et al., 2014), FeeTi (Gupta and Ghosh, 2009), CeeTi (Li et al., 2010), FeeZr (Ren et al., 2011; Gupta et al., 2009), FeeCu (Zhang et al., 2012), MneCo (Zhang et al., 2010), FeeCr (Basu and Ghosh, 2011) and magnetite-graphene oxide (Chandra et al.,

(2009) selected Fe3O4, Mn3O4, and MnFe2O4 nanophases for their studies and reported that bimetal oxide showed comparatively higher adsorption capacity. Zhang et al. (2010) used MnFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 magnetic nanoparticles that were prepared by the chemical coprecipitation method. Paramagnetic nature of these magnetic nanomaterials made its separation easy from solution with magnetic field after adsorption or desorption. Chandra et al. (2010) used magnetite reduced graphene oxide (M-RGO) composites as adsorbent and reported that arsenic (V) ion removal on the M-RGO surface was due to the electrostatic attraction while As (III) ion removal was due to the surface complexation. In the case of As (V) at pH < pHzpc (pHzpc: zero potential charge) signifying more availability of positively charged M-RGO surface that favoured the increased adsorption rates. While in the case of As (III) at pH > pHzpc signifying more availability of negatively charged arsenic species rather than positively charged M-RGO surface that reduced adsorption rates.

sections.heading: 2.1.7. Carbon nano tubes
sections.text: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) provide sufficient adsorption sites as well act as a good supporting material for other adsorbents (Ma et al., 2013). Very few studies on the use of CNTs have been reported for arsenic removal. CNTs are highly porous and have hollow structure. Large specific surface area, light mass density, purity and strong interaction between CNTs and pollutant molecules made the CNTs extensively studied adsorbent. Inspite of these favourable properties of CNTs, the adsorption capacities of metal ions using raw CNTs are very low, but it can be significantly increased after oxidizing the CNTs using HNO3, NaClO and KMnO4 solutions (Fu and Wang, 2011). CNTs in different forms (single walled or multiwalled, closed or open-ended CNTs) have been used for removal of various contaminants. For better adsorption, CNTs modification technique must be selected according to the contaminant of interest. Metal oxides-decorated materials combine the adsorption characteristics of metal oxides and the extraordinary properties of CNTs, such as large surface area, uniformly distributed pores and presence of functional groups on the surface (Chen et al., 2013). Inspite of these spectacular properties, the use of CNTs as adsorbent may also have serious concerns about the health and environmental risks of iron oxide/CNTs once they are released into the environment. These issues may ultimately hinder the scope of practical applications of the iron oxide/CNT composites if the risk assessment would not be considered before selecting it as adsorbent.

sections.heading: 2.1.8.1. Iron doped phenolic-resin based activated carbon.
sections.text:
Sharma et al. (2010) synthesized Fe-incorporated spherical beads (PBFe) of particle size 0.2e1 mm and carbonized that followed by activation. After that they crushed it with ball mill to a particle size of approximately 100 nm. Crushing of beads provides more and rough surface area that accelerates the adsorption of arsenic.
2.1.8.2. Iron cross-linked alginate nanoparticles. Singh et al. (2014) used alginic acid that originates from brown seaweeds and has high affinity towards divalent cations. Each divalentmetal ion binds two carboxyl groups of adjacent alginate molecules (Nestle and Kimmich, 1996). Pre-treatment or doping of alginic acid with cations like Ba2þ, Fe2þ and Ca2þ allows interaction of anionic species of arsenic with the alginate moiety.
2.1.8.3. Dendrimers. No systematic investigations on hydrolytic, oxidative, photochemical and biological stability of dendrimers nanomaterials have been reported so far. Sun et al. (2006) reported application of dendritic polymers that showed good adsorption capacities for silver, mercury and copper, but for arsenic removal its application is not well known. But as dendritic polymers can efficiently be recovered and the adsorbed ions/contaminants can be recycled easily, so it may a potential adsorbent for the arsenic removal from drinking water. Overall studies suggest that nontoxic and biodegradable dendrimers can be synthesized through a judicious selection of the dendrimer building blocks (e.g. core and terminal group) (Savage and Diallo, 2005).

sections.heading: 3. Adsorption process of nanoparticles
sections.text:
According to Gulipalli et al. (2011), the process of adsorption occurs either in single step or in combination of the steps such as film or external diffusion, pore diffusion, surface diffusion and adsorption on the pore surface. It was also reported that adsorption of arsenite and arsenate on the adsorbent surface proceeds in three steps: (1) migration to the surface, (2) dissociation (or deprotonation) of complexed aqueous arsenate or arsenite, and (3) surface complexation (Zhu et al., 2009; Kong et al., 2014). Fig. 1 illustrates the common pathways of adsorption process. Adsorbate (arsenate/ arsenite) is diffused on external surface of the adsorbent (nano adsorbents) due to diffusion potential characterized by the concentrations of adsorbate and available external surface area on the adsorbent (Fig. 1). After diffusion on the external surface of the adsorbent, adsorbate is diffused on the available pores of the
sorption process.

sections.heading: 4.1. Use of supporting materials
sections.text:
Most of the nanomaterials are usually synthesized as suspensions in aqueous solution and are available only in fine powder forms. Therefore, it is not suitable to use these fine powders in column applications, because of their low hydraulic conductivity (Zeng, 2003; Theis et al., 1992). Because of smaller particle size, nano adsorbents cannot be applied in fixed-bed columns unless they are granular in shape or supported on relatively larger size porous materials such as polymers, sand, parent materials of used nano adsorbents, activated carbon etc. But selection of suitable supporting materials for nanoparticles is also problematic. For
example, for metal oxides it is difficult to obtain spherical beads of suitable size for practical applications, so it is required to think of other supporting options instead of preparing beads as supporting materials (Balaji and Matsunaga, 2002). Many researchers studied supporting materials and some of them found good results. Different holding materials reported in the available literature so far have been compiled and presented in Table 1. In general, researchers used packaging materials such as glass wool or glass beads to reduce the fast flow of nanoparticles through column, but it is not sufficient to check or reduce the flow of nanoparticles along with water in the effluent for sufficient period of time. The nonuniformity in flow of treated water cause channelling and fouling of the bed. Another study on holding material (composite gels) for nanoparticles reported that composite gels have unique structure of interconnected large pores, mechanical stability and low flow resistance. In that study nanocomposite devices showed excellent capability for the removal of trace concentrations of As (III) from solution with a total capacity up to 3 mg As/g of nanoparticles (Savina et al., 2011). Montmorillonite as a support material was found useful on tailoring the dispersion and the aggregation behaviour of magnetite nanoparticles, and thus facilitates pelletization, storage, and some related applications. Polyacrylamide has been found as a suitable backbone to use even in mixed ion containing waste water for treatment applications in various studies (Lozinsky et al., 2003; Kirsebom et al., 2009; €Onnby et al., 2012). Some authors in their studies found that holding material itself assisted in adsorption that enhanced the adsorption capacity of the adsorbent. For example, chitosan-graft-polyacrylamide (CTS-g-PA) was used as supporting material by Saha and Sarkar (2012) and observed that the supporting material participated in adsorption along with alumina nanoparticles. Zeolites (hydrated aluminosilicate solids with a cage-like structure) also offered large internal and external surface area for ion exchange. Attia et al. (2012) performed

the adsorption of arsenic onto magnetic nanoparticles coated on zeolite (MNCZ) and observed rapid adsorption due to electrostatic attraction of iron oxides. The high surface area of zeolite mineral and protonated iron-oxide at low pH both participated in enhancing adsorption of negatively charged oxyanionic arsenic (AsO2 4 ) species. Cumbal et al. (2003) studied polymers as supporting material for inorganic nanoparticles. In their study they reported two classes of polymer-supported nanoscale particles: (i) Magnetically Active Polymeric Particles (MAPPs), and (ii) Hydrated Fe (III) Oxide (HFO) dispersed polymeric ion exchanger. Although these are not economically viable, but are reusable and can be reprocessed over many cycles of operation. In a separate study it was mentioned that if an adsorbent has low solubility product then it may be considered as a better filtrationmedium (Basu and Ghosh, 2011). Ghasemzadeh et al. (2014) emphasized the use of natural nanomaterials such as allophane nano clay, surface-modified smectite that are available at geological and pedological origins and may reduce the environmental risk of nanoparticles. Separation and recovery of nano adsorbents remained a challenge after their use.

sections.heading: 4.2. Separation of nanomaterials
sections.text: In the available literature, there are several reported methods for separation of nanoparticles after establishment of the equilibrium during adsorption process such as magnetic separation, filtration and centrifugation method. Separation of nanoparticles from aqueous solution depends on their nature. The separation methods adopted by different researchers are shown in Table 2. Magnetic separation technique has been used to separate magnetite nanoparticles using magnetic field column separator consisting of a stainless steel column (Chandra et al., 2010; Khodabakhshi et al., 2011). Generally, magnetic nanoparticles contain magnetic elements such as iron, nickel, and cobalt. These types of nanoparticles can be separated from water easily by high gradient magnetic separation (HGMS) technique (Ali, 2012). In HGMS method, the separation of nanoparticles depends on magnetic field gradients, magnetic properties, and size of the nanoparticles (Moeser et al., 2004). Mostly iron nanoparticles can be separated by magnetic separation since they have very good magnetic property (Nassar, 2012). Considering size and type of membranes, the process of filtration has been selected by many researchers for separation of akaganeite, carbon nanotubes supported ceria nanoparticles, Fe3O4, nanocrystalline hybrid surfactanteakaganeite and FeO nanoparticles (Deliyanni et al., 2003; Deliyanni and Matis, 2005; Deliyanni et al., 2006; Di et al., 2006; Niu et al., 2005). The centrifugation separation of nanoparticles have been found more effective method for non-magnetic nanoparticles due to its high efficiency, capability of scalable production, free of nanoparticles aggregation and the high density (Chen et al., 2010; Bai et al., 2010). Generally, a centrifuge with a speed of 20,000e50,000 rpm is capable of removing nanoparticles from water. External magnetic field and membrane filtration methods have been used frequently for the separation of nanoparticles from aqueous solution (Ali, 2012). Separation by filtration has been done by various researchers using membrane filter of 0.45 mm (Table 2).

sections.heading: 4.3. Regeneration of nano adsorbents
sections.text:
For practical use of an adsorbent, the regeneration of the adsorbent material is very important to reduce the cost. After adsorption of arsenic, the adsorbent gets exhausted. For reuse of the adsorbent and to recover the adsorbate (arsenic) for safe disposal of the pollutant, regeneration is required. The primary objective of regeneration is to restore the adsorption capacity of the
exhausted adsorbent while the secondary objective is to recover valuable components present in the adsorbed phase. Regeneration of adsorbents makes the adsorption process economically viable. Ali (2012) observed the crucial role of pH in regeneration of adsorbents. From the pH study, it has been found that the adsorption of cations is negligible in the acidic solution and vice-versa for anions. Therefore, desorption could be easily performed by adjusting the solution pH. After regeneration, nano adsorbents can be reused for removal of metallic pollutants, because in many of the cases they are able to retain their adsorption capacity (Sharma et al., 2010). Nano sized iron-oxide-coated quartz (IOCQ)was regenerated using HCl (Mostafa and Hoinkis, 2012).While alkalis are found to be more efficient desorbing agents for regeneration of chemical adsorbents or chemically modified adsorbents (Lata et al., 2015). In most of the available literature, NaOH was found as an effective regenerating agent for regeneration of nano adsorbents. In another desorption study, 25e30% loss was found in adsorption capacity after each desorption cycle for As (V) from akaganeite nanocrystals (Deliyanni et al., 2003). Only 75% of the adsorbed metal could be recovered during a desorption study of arsenic from zerovalent iron onto activated carbon and activated carbon impregnated with nano zerovalent iron adsorbents using 0.1 M NaOH solution (Zhu et al., 2009). Zhang et al. (2012) regenerated synthetic FeeCu binary oxide after 4 cycles and found that after regeneration, the reduction in adsorption capacity for As (V) was only 6.2% and that for As (III) was only 10.6%. That study found NaOH as an efficient regenerating agent for FeeCu binary oxide. Another regeneration study using NaOH (0.05 M) gave even better results with only 6% reduction in adsorption capacity during the regeneration of CTS-g-PA (Saha and Sarkar, 2012).

sections.heading: 5. Comparison of arsenic removal using different nano adsorbents
sections.text:
Use of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal from contaminated groundwater emerged as a very promising method in recent years. Nano adsorbents of various elements like iron, titanium oxide, and iron oxides are found to be comparatively more effective than macro sized adsorbents (Waychunas et al., 2005; Ferguson et al., 2005; Auffan et al., 2008). To help the scientific community, a detailed comparative study for selecting suitable nano adsorbent for arsenic removal has been presented in Table 2. In the year 2003, Deliyanni et al. worked on nano adsorbents and compared various nano adsorbents (such as hydrous iron oxide, ferrihydrite, goethite, hydrous ferric oxide, fly ash etc.) and found that at pH 7.5, arsenic removal (100e120 mg As (V)/g) using akaganeite was comparatively better than other nanoparticles. Kanel et al. (2005) used nano zero valent iron (NZVI) and found removal efficiency of 3.5 mg/g for 1 mg/L (As III) of initial concentration. But for As (V), they found 100% adsorption capacity using the adsorbent dose of only 0.1 g/L (Kanel et al., 2006). They also found that NZVI resulted best performance in acidic and neutral pH. They compared the performance of micron ZVI and NZVI and found that though the removal kinetics of both were similar, but NZVI removed at faster rate and adsorbed As (V) over a wide pH range through the co-precipitation of various iron oxide corrosion products. Again Zhu et al. (2009) used nano zero valent iron (NZVI) along with activated carbon as a holding media (the majority of the NZVI particles used are less than 100 nm in diameter) to remove arsenic from aqueous solution. Study of adsorption capacity resulted 18.2 mg/g of adsorbent for arsenite and 12.0 mg/g for arsenate at pH 6.5. NZVI with activated carbon was recommended as an effective adsorbent compared to other available adsorbents, but interferences due to the presence of ions like phosphate, silicate decreased the adsorption capacity that limits its use. In the same year, Sharma et al. (2010) prepared polymeric beads incorporated with nanoparticles by suspension polymerization, and thenmicro and nano activated carbon particles impregnated with iron were produced. They found better adsorption in the pH range of 6.5e7.5. Polymeric beads with nano size showed good adsorption capacity of 15 mg/g for As (III) and 5 mg/g for As (V). The interesting result was that no pre and post treatments were required for the adsorbent used in that study. In a comparative study, Rahmani et al. (2011) found nano zero valent iron (nZVI) as the better adsorbent than micro zero valent iron (mZVI). Nano zero valent iron showed removal efficiency of 99.9% using adsorbent dose of 1 g/L at contact time of 10 min at pH 7 for initial concentrations of As (III) ranging from 1 to 30 mg/L. Macroporous polymer gel containing nanoparticles of a-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 were also found effective for As (III) removal with efficiency of 3 mg/g at wide range of pH of 3e9 and interference of other ions were also negligible (Savina et al., 2011). But the holding material reduced the adsorption capacity. Attia et al. (2012) used magnetic nanoparticles coated zeolite that resulted 95.6% arsenic removal within 15 min of contact time at pH 2.5. But effectiveness of adsorbent at lower pH restricts its use for drinking water. While Feng et al. (2012) tried with Fe3O4 nanoparticles (diameter of less than 10 nm) coated with ascorbic acid prepared under hydrothermal condition for arsenic removal from waste water in an environmental friendly way. They reported that ascorbic acid improved the dispersibility of Fe3O4 nanoparticles as well as inhibited the leaching of iron into the solution. The maximum adsorption capacity was 16.56 mg/g for arsenic (V), and 46.06 mg/g for arsenic (III). The arsenic removal by this adsorbent was quite impressive with 97.5% removal efficiency using adsorbent dose of 0.06 g/L. pH did not have significant effect on removal efficiency except at pH more than 7 where removal efficiency of the adsorbent decreased to less than 15%. Activated carbon modified with different modifying agents has also been tried and gave good results. In a study, different modified activated carbons (bituminous Filtrasorb-400 (F400-M) obtained from Calgon) were used as adsorbents. These were modified with iron hydroxide/oxide nanoparticles. These iron modified activated carbons were found as efficient adsorbents for removal of initial arsenic concentrations ranging from 0.025 mg/L to 1.5 mg/L. F400-M was found to be the most effective one with adsorption capacity of 0.847 mg/g. But the presence of anions in groundwater such as SO2 4 and Cl
compete for active sites that results in decrease in the adsorption capacity. Regeneration of nano adsorbent was not considered in that study (Vitela-Rodriguez and Rangel-Mendez 2013). In succeeding year, Türk and Alp (2014) used magnetic iron hydrotalcite (M-FeHT) nanoparticles that
were effective inwide range of initial concentrations for removal of both arsenite and arsenate. At pH 9, the adsorption capacities were found to be 1.28 mg/g for As (V) and 0.12 mg/g for As (III).
Aluminium oxides also play an important role in arsenic removal due to its various nano-structured properties and its low cost. In the year 2003, it was reported that mesoporous silica media impregnated with 10% of aluminium by weight (designated as Al10SBA-15) had almost 10.5 times higher adsorption capacity than activated alumina. The initial adsorption rate of Al10SBA-15 was 15 times greater than that of activated alumina. As aluminiumimpregnated SBA-15 provides higher adsorption capacity and rate, it appears to have good potential for arsenate removal. But impregnation techniques need more improvement to reduce the heterogeneity of pore structures and to enhance the surface hydroxyl density so that it may participate in surface complexation and ultimately facilitate better arsenic removal (Jang et al., 2003). In a further study by Hlavay and Poly ak (2005), iron hydroxide-coated aluminawas used as nano adsorbent [Al2O3/Fe(OH)3] and Al2O3 as a support material that removed 3.89 mg/g (As III) and 36.63 mg/g (As V) considering the parameters such as adsorbent dose of 2.5 g/L at pH 6.6e6.7 (for As III), at pH 7.15e7.2 (for As V) and BET surface area (95.7 m2/g). The adsorbent (iron hydroxide-coated alumina) can be directly filled in columns to make the adsorbent low cost for arsenic removal because there is no need of supporting material. €Onnby et al. (2012) evaluated the adsorption capacity of three adsorbents namely SH-groups coupled with a polymer backbone containing amine groups (SH-cryo), aluminium oxide nanoparticles (Alu-NPs) incorporated into cryogels (Alu-NPs cryo), and molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs) incorporated into cryogels. Design of NPs or MIPs using composite materials is a promising way to incorporate small particles which otherwise is difficult to control. Moreover, composites are easy to handle in large scale treatment systems due to their compact design. Among the three adsorbents, Alu-NPs cryo has better adsorption capacity and faster kinetics. The most studied nano size adsorbent is iron based adsorbents such as nano zero valent iron and Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Batch study was performed for wide range of initial arsenic concentrations ranging from 5 to 100 mg/L, but column study was done taking 7 mg/L of initial concentration. In column study, Alu-NPs cryo gave comparatively better results but still it needs some improvements. The study indicated that selective adsorbents can be useful when multiple pollutants are present in raw water for evaluating the adsorption performance of the pollutant of interest. Saha and Sarkar (2012) synthesized an adsorbent by dispersing alumina nanoparticles in chitosan-graft-polyacrylamide (CTS-g-PA). Apart from studying arsenic removal efficiency, they also studied the various influencing factors such as contact time, pH, effects due to the presence of co-ions and regeneration. Polymeric adsorbents were more efficient in arsenic removal than the nano-alumina and CTS-g-PA. The adsorption was explained as a result of both chemical and physical interaction. They recommended this as a noble adsorbent due to three main reasons: (1) lenient operating conditions such as temperature (250 C) and pH 7.2, (2) its high adsorption capacity, and (3) recyclability. Nano-alumina powder is also an efficient nano adsorbent as it can remove arsenite without pre-oxidation of it into arsenate (AseV) from aqueous solution and it was investigated for an initial concentration of 20 mg/L over a pH range of 3.5e8.5 as the synthesized nano g-Al2O3 is insoluble and stable within this range of pH. High adsorptionwas observed in the pH range of 5.5e7.5. Maximum removal of arsenite was achieved within the first 15 min of contact time and equilibrium reached in 30 min. About 97.65% of arsenite removal was achieved within 30 min from the samples containing initial arsenite concentration up to 10 mg/L at pH 7.5. Adsorption isotherms were observed to be well fitted with the Langmuir and D-R models and the maximum
S. Lata, S.R. Samadder / Journal of Environmental Management 166 (2016) 387e406402
adsorption capacity was 40 mg/g (Darban et al., 2013). Copper oxide has also been used by various researchers for arsenic removal. In a study, Martison and Reddy (2009) prepared CuO nanoparticles (surface area of 85 m2/g and diameter of 12e18 nm) and successfully reduced the arsenic level to less than 3 mg/L (0.003 mg/L) in groundwater samples. They found that the adsorption study using CuO nanoparticles best fitted with the Langmuir isotherm, resulted in a maximum adsorption capacity of 26.9 mg/g for As (III) and 22.6mg/g for As (V). At pH 9.3, the highest percentage of As (III) was removed while As (V) found to be independent of pH at the tested pH range. A reaction time of 30minwas suitable for arsenic adsorption. Sulphate and silicate inhibited slightly while high concentration of phosphate (greater than 0.2 mM) reduced the adsorption capacity of arsenic onto CuO. In another study using the same adsorbent, the adsorption capacity of 1.08mg/g was found. The efficiency of arsenic removal was 100% up to 0.2 mg/L of initial arsenic concentrations using 1 g/L of adsorbent dosewith a contact time of 300min, but high pH dependencymade it unsuitable for drinking water treatment. The regeneration of adsorbent was done using NaOH solution and very low desorption was observed, indicating strong attraction force between adsorbent and arsenic. Competing ions such as phosphate and sulphate even at high concentrations can be removed by copper (II) oxide nanoparticles (Goswami et al., 2012).
Titanium dioxide has also been extensively used for arsenic removal (Jing et al., 2005; Bang et al., 2005; Lee and Choi, 2002; Dutta et al., 2004; Pena et al., 2006). In a study for evaluating the efficiency of nanocrystalline titanium dioxide for arsenic removal from solution of 1 mg As/L, an experiment was conducted that resulted adsorption efficiency of greater than 98% for As (V) and 95% for As (III). Titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles were further used as adsorbents in various studies to evaluate adsorption potential for removing arsenic from drinking water (Pena et al., 2006). In a further study, pure and iron-doped TiO2 nanoparticles were synthesized using solegel method and a comparison was done using three types of TiO2 nanoparticles. The first one was general purpose reagent (GPR) TiO2; second one was pure TiO2 and third one was iron-doped TiO2 in air light (AL) and air dark (AD) and nitrogen dark (ND) condition at different pH. The synthesized TiO2 nanoparticles were then immobilized on ordinary sand for adsorption studies. Iron doping enhanced the adsorption capacity of TiO2 nanoparticles by arresting the grain growth and making it visible light responsive resulting in a higher affinity for arsenic. TiO2 possesses a high potential for environmental applications due to its physical and chemical stability, low cost, non-toxicity and the resistance to corrosion. Immobilized TiO2 nanoparticles on a naturally available adsorbent like sand coupled with iron-doping were found as cost effective arsenic treatment technologies. Iron coated titanium oxide gave better adsorption capacity of 20.8 mg/g for As (III) and 19.9mg/g for As (V) in AL systemwhen initial arsenic concentration was 90 mg/L (Deedar et al., 2009). In another study, using titanium oxide as adsorbent, a comparison between nanoparticles coated/embedded macroporous composite adsorbents for As (V) removal was done. That study evaluated that nano sized TiO2 coated perlite (TOCP) has comparatively high adsorption capacity of 0.41 mg/g in batch experiment (Mostafa et al., 2010).
Acetate functionalized zinc oxide nanomaterials of particle size 6e60 nm found to remove the arsenic upto 99% of initial concentration 2 mg/L (Singh et al., 2012).
Some synthetic nano adsorbents (Fe3O4, Mn3O4, and MnFe2O4) prepared by microwave assisted hydrothermal methods have also been investigated for arsenic removal. The binding capacity was 0.03, 0.01, and 0.72 mg/g for As (III) and 1.58, 0.21 and 2.13 mg/g for As (V) respectively for these adsorbents. But MMO's of MnFe2O4 revealed comparatively higher binding capacity for both the arsenic
species at pH 4, reaction time of 15min and adsorbent dose of 2.5 g/ L (Parsons et al., 2009) (Table 2). Magnetite reduced graphene oxide (MRGO) composites removed more than 99.9% arsenic to less than 1 ppb at low temperature (Chandra et al., 2010). Zhang et al. (2010) used bimetal oxide magnetic nanomaterials (MnFe2O4 and CoFe2O4) and found adsorption capacity of 94 mg/g for As (III) and 90 mg/g for As (V) with MnFe2O4; and 100 mg/g for As (III) and 74mg/g for As (V) with CoFe2O4. In this case, pH 3 for As (V) and pH 7 for As (III) with adsorbent dose of 0.2 g/L at temperature 25 C were found favourable for arsenic removal. Adsorption study resulted arsenic removal for a wide range of initial concentrations (0.5e50 mg/L). Desorption study showed that over 80% of As (III) and 90% of As (V) could be desorbed from MnFe2O4 with 0.1 M NaOH solution. Phosphate and silicate were found to be powerful competitors with arsenic for adsorptive sites on the adsorbent. Basu and Ghosh (2011) prepared synthetic nanostructured hydrous Fe (III)eCr (III) (NHICO) mixed oxide for removal of arsenic from aqueous solution. They investigated the effects of incinerating temperature on NHICO, solution pH, and kinetics of As (III) adsorption reaction with NHICO(incinerated at 350 C). Incineration of NHICO at 350 C resulted highest capacity of As (III) removal at pH 7.0 (±0.2) from aqueous phase. Solubility product (Ksp) values were found as 5 10 38 [for Fe(OH)3] and 10 30 [for Cr(OH)3] at 25 C. Thus, the present material (NHICO) can be used safely as a filtration medium due to low solubility in water. Malana et al. (2011) used nano aluminium doped manganese copper ferrite polymer composite as an adsorbent for removal of arsenic from aqueous solution. The nano-composite was prepared by addition of these nano ferrites during co-polymerization of methylacrylate (MA), vinyl acetate (VA) and acrylic acid (AA) monomers using ethylene glycol dimethyl acrylate (EGDMA) and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as cross linking agent and initiator respectively. The maximum adsorption capacity on the nanocomposite was found to be 0.053 mg/g. Freundlich model was found a better fit indicating heterogeneous surface of the adsorbent. Adsorption of arsenic on the nanocomposite followed pseudo-second order kinetics. For evaluation of arsenic removal capacity of nano-structured FeeCu binary oxides, a study was conducted that showed adsorption capacities of 82.7 mg/g for As (V) and 122.3 mg/g for As (III) at pH 7. But researches are still in the process of granulating the nanostructured FeeCu binary oxide particles, which could be readily used in fixed beds. There were no significant effects of co-existing ions such as sulphate and bicarbonate, but the higher concentration of phosphate reduced the arsenic removal (Zhang et al., 2012). Another study compared macro and nano gels for arsenic removal efficiency. These macro gels and nano gels were prepared using 4- vinylpyridine (p-4VP) with redox and micro emulsion techniques. Various parameters such as size of the absorbent, nature of the quaternization agent/modifying agent [(double charge forming agent, 2-bromoethylamine (2-BEA)], treated particles and macro gels, the initial concentration of arsenic, pH and temperature affected the adsorption capacity of As (V). Effect of coexisting ions such as chloride and sulphate ions [(upto 15 mg/L chloride and sulphate did not have any significant effect on As (V) removal)] have also been studied. It was found that with nano sized quaternized (p-4VP)-BE (bromoethane), about 97.1% removal was obtained in just 15 min. These materials can be used upto 5 cycles with very high desorption rate (~80% for macro and ~90% for nanomaterials). Best results were obtained for As (V) removal using nano sized quaternized (p-4VP)-BE (Sahiner et al., 2011).
Ma et al. (2013) used magnetic iron oxide/CNT composites as adsorbent and found the adsorption efficiency efficiency of ~9.74 mg/g for As (V) at pH 4 and ~8.13 mg/g for As(III) at pH 7.5. Chen et al. (2013) used CeeFe mixed oxide decorated multiwalled carbon nanotubes and reported adsorption efficiency of 30.96 mg/g
S. Lata, S.R. Samadder / Journal of Environmental Management 166 (2016) 387e406 403
for As (V) and 28.74mg/g for As (III) using adsorbent dose of 0.2 g/L. Natim and Mitra (2012) used multiwalled carbon nanotubes zirconia nano hybrid that showed adsorption capacity of 2 mg/g for As (III) and 5 mg/g for As (V) at pH 6 and contact time of 300 min.

sections.heading: 6.1. Effect of pH
sections.text: Various nano adsorbents such as nano zero valent iron supported on activated carbon, akeganeite, iron doped activated nano carbon particles, nano zero valent iron, ascorbic acid coated Fe3O4, mesoporous silica media, Al2O3/Fe (OH)3, alumina nanoparticles in chitosan graft polyacrylamide, and nano alumina powder have been reported to remove arsenic from water at the drinking water pH range 6.5e8.5. While some nano adsorbents such as maghemites, titanium dioxide (Deedar et al., 2009), and magnetic nanoparticle coated zeolite (Attia et al., 2012) were found to have better arsenic adsorption capacity at low pH, which are more suitable for arsenic removal fromwaste water rather than drinking water. Most of MMO's nanoparticles have great adsorption capacity for removal of both the arsenic species and As (III) was found to be removed more effectively at drinking water pH range.

sections.heading: 6.2. Effect of synthesis method
sections.text: Synthesis of NZVI was done mostly by reduction method (Kanel et al., 2005, 2006; Zhu et al., 2009; Rahmani et al., 2011; Chandra et al., 2010). Other adsorbents were synthesized by various methods such as chemical precipitation (Basu and Ghose, 2011; Zhang et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2010; Darban et al., 2013; Hlavay and Poly ak, 2005; Türk and Alp, 2014; Delyanni et al., 2003); hydrolysis (Pena et al., 2006; Vitela-Rodriguez and Rangel-Mendez 2013); hydrothermal method (Parsons et al., 2009; Feng et al., 2012); sol gel method (Deedar et al., 2009; Tuutij€arvi et al., 2010); polymerization (Sharma et al., 2010; Savina et al., 2011; €Onnby et al., 2012) and sonication method (Attia et al., 2012). Aluminium oxide was prepared by reverse micro-emulsion (Saha and Sarkar, 2012) or incipient wet impregnation method (Jang et al., 2003); whereas microwave irradiation method (Martinson and Reddy, 2009) and thermal refluxing technique (Goswami et al., 2012) were used for synthesis of copper oxide. Sharma et al. (2010) prepared iron doped phenolic resin based activated carbon nanoparticles by polymerisation method. For the improvement of accessibility of iron to arsenic ions, they incorporated the iron during polymerization process. Researchers should innovate other methods too, to improve the accessibility of nano adsorbents to arsenic ions in an eco-friendly way.

sections.heading: 6.3. Effect of initial concentration
sections.text:
Many of the studies have been carried out using batch studies to understand the maximum uptake of arsenic on nano adsorbents with high initial concentrations of arsenic to provide maximum arsenic available for the nano adsorbents. In actual field condition, groundwater arsenic concentrations may vary from very low concentration to very high concentration. In Table 2, various studies on removal of arsenic concentrations along with their adsorption capacities are presented. A few authors observed excellent adsorption capacity for both the arsenic species, in fact more satisfactory results were observed for As (III) at the drinking water pH range. For example, adsorption capacities of 296.23 mg/g (for As III) and 201.10 mg/g (for As V) for initial concentration of 2 mg/L at pH 7 (Kong et al., 2014), and adsorption capacities of 122.3 mg/g (for As III) and 82.7 mg/g (for As V) for initial concentration of 10 mg/L at
pH 7 (Zhang et al., 2012) were observed. While Deliyanni et al. (2003) found adsorption capacity of 100e200 mg/g only for As (V) at pH 7, but the adsorbent was found efficient to remove arsenic with initial concentrations varying from 5 to 20 mg/L. From Table 2, it is clear that aluminium oxides nanoparticles are comparatively more efficient for the removal of high concentrations of arsenic that may help in effective removal of arsenic from waste water with high arsenic content.

sections.heading: 6.4. Effect of particle size
sections.text: Generally adsorption capacity increases with decrease in particle size, but it is not true for all the adsorbents. For example, zeolite particles are reported to have high surface area, but adsorption capacity of larger crystals was found to be more rather than smaller particles (Vignola et al., 2005, 2008) due to the intra-crystalline pore structure of zeolite (Rouquerol et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 6.5. Effect of competing ions
sections.text:
To study the influence of interfering agents on the arsenic removal using NZVI, Tanboonchuy et al. (2012) used six species including SO2 4 , PO 3 4 , HCO 3 , Ca
2þ, Cl , and humic acid (HA) in a study and concluded that HA, SO2 4 and PO 3 4 have inhibitory effects, but Ca2þ has enhancing effect. Presence of HCO 3 has inhibitory effect on the removal of both the arsenic species. Increased Ca2þ concentrations and decreased PO3 4 and HA concentrations create the condition for best removal of both As (III) and As (V). In arsenic removal, silicate and phosphate were found to have comparatively more interference (that reduced the adsorption of arsenic) than NO 3 , SO 2 4 , and HCO 3 (Kanel et al., 2005, 2006; Zhu et al., 2009). While Savina et al. (2011) found negligible effects of these interfering agents (Table 2). Martison and Reddy (2009), Kong et al. (2014) and Zhang et al. (2010) also reported the interference of sulphate, phosphate and silicate in arsenic removal. But for As (V), their effect was found negligible (Martinson and Reddy, 2009; Natim and Mitra, 2012).

sections.heading: 6.6. Effect of contact medium
sections.text:
Different contact medium such as packed beds, packed bed with nanoparticles coated media, fluidized beds, etc. have been reported in literature to explain the way of application of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal fromwater (Table 1). For arsenic removal, there are very few column studies reported in available literature and most of them found to be supported packed bed column studies. While for column studies both packed bed and fluidized bed can be used depending on type of adsorbents. For example, adsorbent of acceptable hydraulic conductivity is suitable for fixed bed, while adsorbent of low hydraulic conductivity found to be less suitable for packed bed column. Coating of nano adsorbents on the material of high hydraulic conductivity can solve this problem. In packed bed column study, continuous operation becomes difficult because of channelling and fouling due to non-uniformity of flow accompanied by loss of smaller size (nano) particles. Nano adsorbents with or without supporting material should also be of sufficient compressive strength, so that it can resist the hydraulic shock that may lead to the fracturing of the adsorbent in a packed bed (Chen et al., 2011). Fluidized bed can also be used for nanoparticles if the adsorbent is coated with such materials that restrict the agglomeration of nanoparticles in fluidized state. Less coating results the low adsorption capacity while more number of layers can be easily shedded off, which leaves the coated sand with little adsorption capacity and causes secondary pollution in drinking water (Chen et al., 2009) that nececiated the researchers to use
S. Lata, S.R. Samadder / Journal of Environmental Management 166 (2016) 387e406404
acrylic-styrene copolymer latex as binding agent. Other polymers, such as polyacrylamide (PAM) and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) were also found as promising binders. A low cost “green” starchwas used as a stabilizer to prevent the agglomeration of magnetite nanoparticles and as a bridging agent for allowing the nanoparticles to flocculate and precipitatewithmaintaining high arsenic adsorption capacity (An et al., 2011).
Application of nano adsorbents are found to be more effective in removal of both arsenite and arsenate from contaminated water. It has been found that even waste water pollutants with high arsenic concentrations can be effectively removed using different nano adsorbents with a relatively small amount of adsorbent and short time. The nanoparticles should have good adsorption capacity at the pH range 6.5e8.5 with low adsorbent dose for initial concentration upto 10 mg/L for selection of nanoparticles as the adsorbent for arsenic removal from drinking water. The metal used as nano adsorbent should not leach into treated water beyond its permissible limit, otherwise a suitable coating with appropriate material should be provided to stop leaching. MMO's nanoparticles found to have comparatively better adsorption capacity at drinkingwater pH range, competing ions do not hinder the adsorption capacity and easily regenerable by NaOH. If the suitable supporting material is explored for MMO's nanoparticles, it may prove to be an effective feasible solution for the removal of arsenic at field condition.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: This paper thoroughly reviewed the application and challenges in the selection of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal. This study also critically analyzed the desorption and separation studies available for various nano adsorbents. The practical applicability of nano adsorbents in field conditions (such as applicability of adsorbent on a wide range of arsenic concentrations with better adsorption efficiency and regeneration of nano adsorbents) requires more attention. Considering the various studies reported so far, it is concluded that aluminium oxides for waste water and MMO's nanoparticles for drinking water may be the better option for arsenic removal. Adsorption potential, high surface area, physical and chemical stability, solubility product of adsorbent, holding materials (should be such that it participates in adsorption to enhance adsorption capacity of the adsorbent), hydraulic conductivity of adsorbent, leachability of metallic nanoparticles into the treated water, separation process of nano adsorbents from aqueous solution, cost effectiveness, field applicability, environmental impact and risk assessment should be considered before selection of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal. The study will help the readers to choose appropriate nanomaterials, to select suitable holding materials for nano adsorbents for field application and to understand the further research required for arsenic removal using nano adsorbents.

metadata.abstractText: Many researchers have used nanoparticles as adsorbents to remove water pollutants including arsenic after modifying the properties of nanoparticles by improving reactivity, biocompatibility, stability, charge density, multi-functionalities, and dispersibility. For arsenic removal, nano adsorbents emerged as the potential alternatives to existing conventional technologies. The present study critically reviewed the past and current available information on the potential of nano adsorbents for arsenic removal from contaminated water and the challenges involved in that. The study discussed the separation and regeneration techniques of nano adsorbents and the performance thereof. The study evaluated the adsorption efficiency of the various nanoparticles based on size of nanoparticles, types of nano adsorbents, method of synthesis, separation and regeneration of the nano adsorbents. The study found that more studies are required on suitable holding materials for the nano adsorbents to improve the permeability and to make the technology applicable at the field condition. The study will help the readers to choose suitable nanomaterials and to take up further research required for arsenic removal using nano adsorbents. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
